pullRequest.body:
This is a specialization of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality which is often useful in math olympiad problems.

Co-authored-by: Alex Brodbelt <64128135+AlexBrodbelt@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: Heather Macbeth <25316162+hrmacbeth@users.noreply.github.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ed2ff54fd5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19311/commits/ed2ff54fd5d2c47e724cff22acdee1f4ffedfbdc)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ sq_sum_div_le_sum_sq_div`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Orthogonal to my question above, I wonder if we want the "generalized form" from https://brilliant.org/wiki/titus-lemma/#generalized-form as well.
I didn't even know there was a generalized form! I think we can add it later if it ever becomes useful for anything.
It seems a little unfortunate that this lemma only works for `Real` and not `NNReal`. Presumably it's also true for `Rat`?
It should be true for any linearly ordered field, the same way Cauchy-Schwarz is. But if CS isn't in Mathlib then I don't think there's much case in trying to generalize this inequality.
(I don't actually know how you'd prove Sedrakyan for linear ordered fields, other than to work in the quadratic closure. For Cauchy-Schwarz the proof with bilinear forms generalizes directly.)

> But if CS isn't in Mathlib then I don't think there's much case in trying to generalize this inequality.

I don't really understand what you mean by that. Cauchy-Schwarz is in mathlib in the general case, but your application of the lemma requires a square root function which obviously doesn't work for Rat. So the loss of generality seems to be a function of your proof, not of the lemmas in mathlib.

If the generalization is awkward a TODO would suffice.

> requires a square root function which obviously doesn't work for Rat

What about taking a real closure (do we have this in mathlib?), or simply taking a real quadratic extension?

Ah, sorry. I think I saw the earlier theorems in this file (the ones about square roots) were specific to real numbers and assumed the same for `Finset.sum_mul_sq_le_sq_mul_sq`.

I've shot my shot at [Stack Exchange](https://math.stackexchange.com/q/5001456/718671) asking for a proof of Sedrakyan without field extensions. If anyone can come up with that then we'll be able to avoid a lot of shenanigans :)

I think what's actually needed is a more general version of `sum_mul_sq_le_sq_mul_sq`, where `f i ^ 2` and `g i ^ 2` are replaced by arbitrary nonnegative values (not necessarily squares, to avoid needing square roots); given the more general Cauchy-Schwarz in semirings, this result should follow. That is, something like

```lean
lemma sum_sq_le_sum_mul_sum_of_sq_eq_mul (s : Finset ι) {t f g : ι → R}
    (ht : ∀ i, t i ^ 2 = f i * g i) (hf : ∀ i, 0 ≤ f i) (hg : ∀ i, 0 ≤ g i) :
    (∑ i ∈ s, t i) ^ 2 ≤ (∑ i ∈ s, f i) * ∑ i ∈ s, g i := by
  sorry
```

(for `[LinearOrderedCommSemiring R] [ExistsAddOfLE R]`, like the original). The existing proof of `sum_mul_sq_le_sq_mul_sq` uses `two_mul_le_add_sq` as the essential use of "squares are nonnegative"; instead you probably need a lemma of the form `2 * t ≤ a + b` given `t ^ 2 = a * b`, `0 ≤ a` and `0 ≤ b` (don't know if we already have it, but it follows in an ordered semiring by squaring both sides).

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Real/Sqrt): Sedrakyan's lemma
